Term.Name: ANIMATION DEPARTMENT

These frames may be generated by computers, or by photographing a drawn or painted image, or by repeatedly making small changes to a model unit (see claymation and stop motion), and then photographing the result with a special animation camera.

Term.Name: Character Animator
Term.Definition: Character animation is a special aspect of the animation process, in which life is breathed into an artificial character. It involves creating the nuances, gestures, distinct movements, and patterns of speech that will make an audience believe that the character is actually alive

Term.Definition: A person responsible for the creation of an animated work. This encompasses all kinds of animation including cartoons, computer generated animations and still frame animations using models.

Term.Name: Rotoscope Paint Artist
Term.Definition: Rotoscoping is a technique where animators trace live action movement, frame by frame, for use in animated cartoons. Originally, pre-recorded live-film images were projected onto a matte windowpane and redrawn by an animator. This projection equipment is called a Rotoscope.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Background Artist / Background Stylist / Background Painter
background artist
background stylist
background painter
Term.Definition: A background artist or sometimes called a background stylist or background painter is one who is involved in the process of animation who establishes the color, style, and mood of a scene drawn by an animation layout artist. He paint the sets over which the action of each animated sequence will take place.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Lead Digital Texture
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Compositor / Compositing Artist
compositor
compositing artist
Term.Definition: In visual effects post-production, compositing refers to creating complex images or moving images by combining images from different sources - such as real-world digital video, digitized film, synthetic 3-D imagery, 2-D animations, painted backdrops, digital still photographs, and text. Compositors are often specialised in software and applications such as Inferno or Flame and known e.g. as Inferno or Flame artists.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Puppeteer
Term.Definition: A person who operates a puppet within a performance. For the purposes of this definition puppets include glove puppets, internally controlled hand puppets, string or wire controlled marionettes and other animatronic creations which move in real time.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Pixilation
Term.Definition: Pixilation (from pixilated) is a stop motion technique where live actors are used as a frame-by-frame subject in an animated film, by repeatedly posing while one or more frame is taken and changing pose slightly before the next frame or frames. The operator is responsible for capturing this material.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: ART DEPARTMENT
Term.Definition: Art department in movie terms means the section of a production's crew concerned with visual artistry. Working under the supervision of the production designer and/or art director, the art department is responsible for arranging the overall look of the film (i.e. modern/high-tech, rustic, futuristic, etc.) as desired by the film director. The Art Department in a major section of a production with several key sub departments.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Production Designer / Draughtsman / Draftsman
production designer
draughtsman
draftsman
Term.Definition: Responsible for sets, props and costumes. An artist responsible for designing the overall visual appearance of a programme in collaboration with the director, art director, technical director and cinematographer.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Assistant Production Designer
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Art
Term.Definition: Department where the sets are designed and graphic art is created.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Art Director
Term.Definition: An art director, in the hierarchical structure of a film art department, works directly below the production designer, and above the set designer, but on the same level as the set decorator. He oversees the artists and craftspeople who build the sets
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Supervising Art Director
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Assistant Art Director
Term.Definition: Often involved in measuring locations, creating graphics and paper props, collecting information for the production designer and drawing sets.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Set Decorator / Set Designer
set decorator
set designer
Term.Definition: A set decorator is in charge of the set dressing on a film set, which includes the furnishings, wallpaper, lighting fixtures, and many of the other objects that will be seen in the film. The set designer reports to the art director.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Set Decorator Assistant
Term.Definition: The set decorator assistant works closely with the set decorator and / or production designer in coordination with the art director
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Set Decoration Buyer
Term.Definition: The buyer is the number two person in the set department below the set decorator. The buyer locates, and then purchases or rents the set dressing.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Leadman / Leadperson / Set Supervisor
leadman
leadperson
set supervisor
Term.Definition: Member of the art department who is in charge of the groups in the art department that construct and take down a set (swing gangs), and/or set dressers and reports to the set decorator.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Set Dresser
Term.Definition: A person who has total charge of decorating the set for shooting with all furnishings, drapery, interior plants, and anything seen on indoor or outdoor sets.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Set Maker
Term.Definition: A person who makes the set with the specifications dictated by the set designer
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

property master

prop builder
prop maker
property builder
property maker
Term.Definition: The props builder, as the name implies, builds the props that are used for the film. Props builders are often technicians skilled in construction, plastics casting, machining, and electronics.

Term.Name: Prop Assistant / Property Assistant

Term.Name: Armourer
Term.Definition: The person responsible for the supply and safety of any weapons used in a production. The armourer's role is to ensure that any ordinance, firearms or other weapons are safely stored and safely used. Note: not to be confused with Fight Director

Term.Name: Head Carpenter
Term.Definition: The head carpenter is the foreman of a "gang" of carpenters and labourers.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Carpenter
Term.Definition: A person employed to carry out any woodwork which the production may require (e.g. for set building)

Term.Name: Scenic
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Scenic Designer
Term.Definition: Scenic Designers are responsible for creating scale models of the scenery as well as scale drawings.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Key Scenic Artist
Term.Definition: The key scenic artist is responsible for the surface treatments of the sets. This includes special paint treatments such as aging and gilding, as well as simulating the appearance of wood, stone, brick, metal, stained glassanything called for by the production designer. The key scenic artist supervises the crew of painters, and is often a master craftsperson.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Scenic Artist / Painter
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Scenic Operative
Term.Definition: Scenic Operatives set, rig, strike and dress studio sets. This can also involve erecting rostra, audience seating etc and making running repairs or painting floors and scenery.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Greens
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Greensman
Term.Definition: The greensman is a specialised set dresser dealing with the artistic arrangement of plant material, sometimes real and sometimes artificial. Depending on the scope of the greens work in a film, the greensman may report to the set decorator or may report directly to the production designer.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Graphic Designer
Term.Definition: Person responsible for the design and realisation of original graphic material. This includes developing design concepts, using working drawings, storyboards and electronic paint images. They also design title sequences.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Graphic Assistant
Term.Definition: Person involved in making day-to-day paintbox pictures, and drawing completely or partially synthetic picture elements as content for programmes with existing graphic design format. Note: not to be confused with Graphic Designer, Illustrator
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Illustrator
Term.Definition: Person responsible for the illustrations used in the programme Note: not to be confused with Graphic Assistant

Term.Name: Compositor / Compositing Artist
compositor
compositing artist
Term.Definition: Artists composing scenes often specialised in software and applications such as Inferno or Flame and known as Inferno or Flame artists. Digital compositing is the process of assembling multiple images to make a final image, typically for print, motion pictures or screen display.

Term.Name: CG Artist / CG Designer
CG artist
CG designer
Term.Definition: An artist who produces computer graphics (CG) where one utilizes computers both to generate visual images synthetically and to integrate or alter visual and spatial information sampled from the real world
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Dialogue Editor
Term.Definition: The dialogue editor assembles, synchronises, and edits all the dialogue in a film or television production
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Special Effects (SFX)
Term.Definition: Special effects (abbreviated SPFX or SFX) are used in the film, television, and entertainment industry to visualize scenes that cannot be achieved by normal means, such as space travel. They are also used when creating the effect by normal means is prohibitively expensive, such as an enormous explosion. They are also used to enhance previously filmed elements, by adding, removing or enhancing objects within the scene. Special Effects are those effects which are created during filming on-set, such as bullet hits, fire, flame, and explosions, wind, rain, etc.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Special Effects (SFX) Assistant
Term.Definition: A person who makes an artificial effect used to create an illusion in a program including technicians
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Special Effects (SFX) Supervisor
Term.ChangeComment: Duplication with 5.10.4

Term.Name: Special Effects buyer

Term.Name: Special Effects (SFX) Supervisor
Term.Definition: Person responsible for the artificial effects produced on the set and used to create an illusion in a movie. Note: not to be confused with visual effects

matte artist
bluescreen editor
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Matte Painter
Term.Definition: A person who creates artwork (usually for the background or forreground of a shot) which is included in the movie either via a matte shot or optical printing. It can be computer generated. A travelling matte allows the shape and position of the matte to be altered from frame to frame.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: CAMERA DEPARTMENT
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Director of Photography
Term.Definition: "Person with overall responsibility for conception, design, and capture of the visual appearance of an audio-visual work. Possible duties are: selection of film stock, cameras, and lenses; designing and selecting lighting, directing the gaffer's placement of lighting; shot composition (in consultation with the director); film developing and film printing." Note: not to be confused with Photographer
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Film
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Cinematographer
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Chief Camera Segment
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Camera Operator / Camera Person / Cameraman
camera operator
camera person
cameraman
Term.Definition: Also called cameraman. The camera operator uses the camera at the direction of the cinematographer, director of photography, or the film director to capture the scenes on film or video
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: First Assistant Camera Operator / Focus Puller
first assistant camera operator
focus puller
assistant camera
Term.Definition: Responsible for keeping the camera in focus as it is shooting. Also maintains the camera during the duration of the filming period, apply or remove any necessary or unnecessary accessories (such as matte boxes, lens changes, filters, external viewing monitors, video assist devices, etc.), reload the camera (whether with film or video tape) and oversee the 2nd Assistant camera operator and any other members of the camera assist team (including desiginated loaders and camera production assistants).
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Second Assistant Camera / Clap Boy / Clapper Loader
second assistant camera
clap boy
clapper loader
assistant camera
Term.Definition: Operates the clapperboard at the beginning of each take and loads the raw film stock into the camera magazines between takes. Also in charge of delivering film material to development labs, he oversees organization of camera equipment and transport of the equipment from one shooting location to another.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Steadycam Operator
Term.Definition: Person in charge of the operation of a camera and responsible for the device's output during a production. Also called cameraman
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: High Definition Supervisor
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: High Definition Camera Assistant
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Steadycam Assitant
Term.Definition: Person in charge of the operation of a camera and responsible for the device's output during a production. Also called cameraman
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Jib Operator
Term.Definition: A jib is boom device with a camera on one end, and a counterweight and camera controls on the other.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Underwater Operator
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Loader
Term.Definition: transfer film from the manufacturer's light-tight canisters to the camera magazines for attachment to the camera
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Switcher
Term.Definition: A person (studio engineer) responsible for camera mixing or switching. Switching is the selection process among the various audio and video sources in a production
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Digital Imaging Engineer
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Digital Imaging Technician / DIT
Term.Definition: On digital photography productions the digital imaging technician is responsible for the coordination of the internal workings of the digital camera. Under the direction of the cinematographer or director of photography, the DIT will make adjustments to the multitude of variables available in most professional digital cameras to creatively or technically manipulate the resulting image.

Term.Name: Camera Tracking Artist / Matchmove Artist
camera tracking artist
matchmove artist
Term.Definition: Camera tracking or matchmoving refers to the process of matching the position and angle of CGI (such as a spaceship or animated creature) to real footage shot with a film or video camera. This process can be accomplished manually on a frame by frame basis. More common is the use of automated matchmoving software based on computer vision techniques that can extract camera position and rotation values over time from a frame sequence of digitized footage with minimal user intervention. Done correctly, matchmoving allows the seamless compositing of additional elements into camera footage that may have been too expensive or impossible to achieve otherwise.

Term.Definition: ADR automatic dialogue replacement is the process of replacing dialogue that was recorded incorrectly during filming, with the actors voices recorded and put into place during editing. The ADR editor oversees the procedure and takes the corrupted dialogue, and replaces it with newly recorded lines to the actor's mouth on film to make it lip sync correctly.Automated dialogue replacement is called post-synchronisation (post-sync)

Occasionally, it is used to refer to a person who is responsible for creating unique sounds or sound elements which are incorporated into a sound track

Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Assistant Grip
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Dolly Grip
Term.Definition: In cinematography, the dolly grip is the individual who places and moves the dolly track were it is required, and then pushes and pulls the dolly along that track while filming. A dolly grip must work closely with the camera crew to perfect these complex movements during rehearsals. For moving shots, dolly grips may also push the wheeled platform holding the microphone and boom operator. The dolly is a cart that the tripod and camera (and occasionally the camera crew) rest on. It makes the camera able to move without bumps and visual interruptions from start to finish while the camera is filming. It is commonly used to follow beside an actor to give the audience the sense of walking with the actor, or as the actor.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Rigging Key Grip
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Musician / Instrumentalist / Player
musician
instrumentalist
player
Term.Definition: Someone who plays a musical instrument (as a profession) including instrumentalits or other instrument player
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Choir
Term.Definition: An organised company of singers
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Ensemble
Term.Definition: A group of musicians playing or singing together. Especially for classical music.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Music Group
Term.Definition: A group of musicians playing and singing together. Especially for popular music (pop/rock).
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Orchestra
Term.Definition: A group of musicians performing in a concerted manner. Typically a band suitable for the performance of synphonies, ouvertures, etc., as well as for the accompaniment of operas, oratorios, cantatas, masses, and the like, or of vocal and instrumental solos.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Singer / Vocalist
singer
vocalist
Term.Definition: A person who uses his or her voice with or without instrumental accompaniment to produce music. A singer's performance may or may not include actual words.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Synthesis Musician
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: NEWS DEPARTMENT
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: News Director
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Editor/Producer (News)
editor (news)
producer (news)
Term.Definition: Person responsible for deciding which stories to include and which to leave out for a News programme. Note: not to be confused with
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Assistant Editor
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Editor in Chief
Term.Definition: Head of the editorial staff for news output on a particular service.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Editor of the day
Term.Definition: Journalist responsible for the (news) broadcast of the day
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Announcer
Term.Definition: A person, appearing in sound or in vision, responsible for reading newscast and news bulletins, for voices continuity for programs, or for describing actualities such as parades, sporting, musical and other special events.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: News Reader
Term.Definition: A person, typically a journalist, who reads news stories in news programmes.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Broadcast Journalist / Video Journalist
broadcast journalist
video journalist
Term.Definition: Person who decides how a story should be written, which facts are important and how to edit sound and vision. He/She reports, edits, writes scripts, reads bulletins and compiles pages for teletext services and online. He/She is the responsible for a news story of which may be indicated as the author.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Reporter
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Correspondent
Term.Definition: Correspondents comment on events within their own specialist area, enabling us to provide an authoritative view on the news stories of the day.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Witness
Term.Definition: An interviewed person speaking about something (generally newsworthy) of which they have first hand experience.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: POST-PRODUCTION
Term.Definition: Everything after the shooting of the film is post production. People involved in this stage of production include the editor, the publicist, the sound editor, the Foley artist, the composer, the title sequence designer, and the specialist editors.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Post-production Producer
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Post-production Editor
Term.Definition: The role of the Post Production Editor is to help determine the look, sound and feel of the finished programme. The editor uses creative skills to set the pace of the piece and to further tighten the relationship between the picture and sound.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Post-production Executive
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Post-production Scheduler
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Post-production Supervisor
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Post-production Coordinator / Clearance Coordinator
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Post-production Audio
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Post-production Video
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Post-production Film
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Post-production Tape Operator
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Post-production Technician
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: PRODUCTION
Term.Definition: These include the "front office" staff such as the Production Manager, the Production Coordinator, and their assistants; the accounting staff; the various Assistant Directors; and sometimes the Locations Manager and his or her assistants. The Director is considered to be a separate entity, not within the departmental structure.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Producer
Term.Definition: A person who is responsible for the making of an audio-visual work, including business aspects, management of the productions, and the commercial success of the work within scheduled deadlines.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Executive Producer
Term.Definition: The person primarily in charge of the financial aspects of a overall production and who may also make major creative decisions. He is not involved in any technical aspects of the filmmaking process. Typically an executive producer handles business and legal issues. He may supervise one or more producers or co-producers.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Supervising Producer
Term.Definition: The supervising producer coordinates the activities of more than one producer under the authority of the executive producer.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Assistant Executive Producer
Term.Definition: Assistant to the Executive Producer
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Line Producer
Term.Definition: The line producer works with the production manager on operating and more particulaly financial aspects.Line Producer: He approves expenses, including locations, actors, and crew.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Associate Producer
Term.Definition: The top assistant to the producer, usually the intermediary between the Producer and the shooting crew.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Co-Producer
Term.Definition: Producer participating in a collaborative production effort with other co-producers
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Segment Producer
Term.Definition: The segment producer is in charge of supervising the production of one or more segments of a programme or film
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Assistant Producer
Term.Definition: Assistant Producers assist Producers in the production of programmes or series. They are responsible for defining the best format corresponding to the programme / film intention and targeted audience. Assistant Producers set up filming, find interviewees, archive material and locations, and on some productions they suggest and book studio guests. They supervise the post-production process, being involved in editing, dubbing and compilation. Note: not to be confused with Production Assistant.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Production Manager
Term.Definition: The individual under the producer and director who supervises and coordinates all of the business and technical aspects of production. Production Manager Organises and oversees a production including keeping a tight rein on the budget. Organises all the essential support facilities - accommodation, catering, transport, etc. and will roster crews, equipment and facilities. The Production Manager often works under the supervision of a line producer and directly supervises the Production Coordinator
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Unit Manager / Second Unit Manager
unit manager
second unit manager
Term.Definition: The person acting as production manager in charge of the second unit. This is a group charged with filming the less important scenes in a production. Note: not to be confused with Assistant Director.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Assistant Unit Manager / Assistant Second Unit Manager / Unit Manager / Unit Production Manager
assistant unit manager
Assistant second unit manager
unit manager
unit production manager
Term.Definition: Assist with the day-to-day financial operation of the shooting unit.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Mobile Unit Supervisor
Term.Definition: The unit supervisor is under the responsibility of a unit manager for secondary "mobile unit" shooting.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Production Coordinator
Term.Definition: The Production Coordinator is at the heart of the production process under the responsibility of the production manager, responsible for organizing all the logistics from hiring crew, renting equipment, booking talent, etc.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Assistant Coordinator
Term.Definition: Assitant to the Production Coordinator.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Director
Term.Definition: He controls the action and dialogue in front of the camera. The person mainly responsible for the artistic result of the work, including controlling the content and flow of the film's plot, directing the performances of actors, organizing and selecting the locations in which the film will be shot (shooting script), and managing technical details such as the positioning of cameras, the use of lighting, and the timing and content of the film's soundtrack, that is for taking the script to the very end of the production process. The director role may differ whether it is for television or film, e.g. one shoots on set while the other direct from the galley. The television director views the action on the studio floor through a bank of screens, each one linked to one of the studio cameras, while issuing instructions down to the Floor Manager. In television, the creative part in the hands of the producer.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: First Assistant Director
Term.Definition: The first assistant director assists the director and production manager. He runs the set, plans the cost-efficient scheduling of locations and talent, schedules the days shooting and is responsible for carrying out the directors instructions.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Second Assistant Director
Term.Definition: The second assistant director handles paperwork relating to the number of hours worked, scheduling, booking, etc. He is occasionally in charge of production assistants as chief assistant.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Associate Director
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Artistic Director
Term.Definition: The person mainly responsible for the artistic result of the work, including controlling the content and flow of the film's plot, directing the performances of actors, organizing and selecting the locations in which the film will be shot (shooting script), and managing technical details such as the positioning of cameras, the use of lighting, and the timing and content of the film's soundtrack, that is for taking the script to the very end of the production process. The director role may differ whether it is for television or film, e.g. one shoots on set while the other direct from the galley. The television director views the action on the studio floor through a bank of screens, each one linked to one of the studio cameras, while issuing instructions down to the Floor Manager. In television, the creative part in the hands of the producer.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Segment Director
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Television Galley / Control Room Team
television galley
control room team
Term.Definition: The following crew positions are only utilised on a multi-camera production. The Gallery or "Control Room" is a separate darkened area away from the studio floor where the action can be viewed across multiple monitors and controlled from a single source.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Vision Mixer / Vision Switcher
vision mixer
vision switcher
Term.Definition: The person responsible for mixing video feeds in a live programme, such as a news broadcast. The Vision Mixer is also responsible for the actual switching between different video sources, such as camera shots and video inserts. They also maintain colour and contrast balance between the studio cameras.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Aston Operator / Graphics Operator
aston operator
graphics operator
Term.Definition: The Aston Operator prepares and displays on-screen graphics.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: VT Operator
Term.Definition: The VT Operator cues and prepares video inserts into a programme. Heavily used in sports programming, they are also responsible for action replays and quickly editing highlights while a show is in progress.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Production Assistant
Term.Definition: He brings a specific production together. Chooses the screenplay, arranges financing, hires a director, helps in the casting process, coordinates the production teams, contributors and artists, and is responsible for the day-to-day operation of the shoot on set or from a studio galley (shot calling, shot-listing, making recording notes, cueing, liaison with Presentation / VT, timing and continuity noting; preparing operational and post-production documentation including programme scripts, camera scripts / cards; recording orders, script breakdowns, schedules edit notes and post production scripts). He is involved with the editing and all post-production and may also consult on marketing and distribution. This function is different from the one of assistant producer. In television, they are responsible for communication with the broadcasting channel during a live show, counting down the time before transmission aloud to the crew via the studio microphone. They also count down time remaining for sections of a programme, such as an interview or an advert break. Prior to a production, he is responsible for preparing and timing the script, noting pre-recorded inserts, sound effects and suchlike, and for clearing copyright and other administrative issues.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Production Researcher
Term.Definition: A Person who carries out research required for the making of a production. This may be research to do with the subject matter of the programme such as nackground information, supporting material, or in finding persons to take part.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Production Assistant Researcher
Term.Definition: A Person who carries out research required for the making of a production. This may be research to do with the subject matter of the programme such as nackground information, supporting material, or in finding persons to take part.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Senior Researcher
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Production Auditor
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Production Secretary
Term.Definition: Fulfils traditional secretarial duties assigned to the production and provides general administrative support.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Production Steward
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Production Company
Term.Definition: Organisation responsible for producing the material
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Production Department
Term.Definition: Department of the production company, or of the commissioning broadcaster, responsible for producing the material
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Production Unit
Term.Definition: It is composed of camera crew, lighting/electrical department, sound crew, etc.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Commissioning Broadcaster
Term.Definition: Original broadcaster commissioning the material.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Commissioning Channel
Term.Definition: Channel commissioning the material.
Term.ChangeComment: TV-Anytime maintenance 2010

Term.Name: Commissioning Brand
Term.Definition: Brand commissioning the material.
Term.ChangeComment: TV-Anytime maintenance 2010

Term.Name: Technical Director
Term.Definition: Television production. In a production control room, the technical director has overall responsibility for the operations. The technical director is responsible for the proper working of all the equipment in the PCR. They also matches the quality and the output of all the cameras on the studio floor through the camera control units. It is their responsibility to supervise all the other crew members working in the PCR. The technical director also coordinates the working of the whole crew and looks into any technical problem which arises before, during or after the shooting of a project
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Script Editor / Story Editor
Term.Definition: A script editor a position sometimes known as story editor is a member of the production team of scripted television programmes, usually dramas and comedies. The script editor's main job is to work with the writers of the programme to ensure that the scripts are suitable for production the script editor, unlike the writers, will usually be a full-time member of the production team, working closely with the producer
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Resource Manager
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Shop Lead
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Floor Manager / Stage Manager / Foreman
floor manager
stage manager
foreman
Term.Definition: For television, the Floor Manager is the Director's representative on the studio floor, and is responsible for giving instruction and direction to crew, cast and guests. The Floor Manager is responsible for everything that happens on the floor and acts as liaison between the director and studio staff.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Assistant Floor Manager
Term.Definition: An Assistant Floor Manager is responsible for setting a stage and prompting contributors on the studio floor and ensuring that everyone knows their place in the script, freeing the Floor Manager for other duties. They often oversee a team of Runners. Increasingly, Assistant Floor Managers are being asked to assist with the design and preparation of props, as well as setting and resetting the action on the studio floor.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Scheduling Director
Term.Definition: Scheduling directors organize the production schedule. They prepare an efficient schedule for shooting scenes, taking into account the individual schedules of each crew and cast member and the availability of the set location.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Runner
Term.Definition: Runners are the most junior members of a television or film crew. The job can include holding back onlookers, getting coffee, answering phones in the production office, escorting actors to locations, acting as a stand-in while a short is worked out, or performing any other tasks helping the production in any way.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Location Manager
Term.Definition: The location manager assists the Director and the Production designer in finding, securing, and coordinating filming locations. Locations is often considered to be a separate department. He works with local officials to coordinate shooting schedules, and is responsible for the condition of the locations after shooting is finished. He often acts as location scout during the pre-production period
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Assistant Location Manager
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Location Scout
Term.Definition: Same role as location manager to find filimng locations in particular during the pre-production period
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Third Assistant Director
Term.Definition: Person that works on set with the 1st and sometimes 2nd Assistant Director. For major productions only.
Term.ChangeComment: TVA-Maintenance 2011

Term.Name: Format Deviser
Term.Definition: Person who devises the format of a programme, including development of the main elements of the programme, such as concept, characters, sometimes which actors, performers or crew should be involved.

Term.Name: Music Adviser
Term.Definition: Person who provides advice on the music used in a programme.

Term.Name: Stage Designer
Term.Definition: Person responsible for look of a production (e.g. set, props, costumes). Theatrical productions only.

Term.Name: Stage Director
Term.Definition: Person responsible for supervising all audience-visible components of show. Theatrical productions only.

Term.Name: Stage Lighting Director
Term.Definition: Person who is responsible for lighting the set. Theatrical productions only.

Term.Name: Stage Production Manager
Term.Definition: Person responsible overall for stage management. Theatrical productions only.

Term.Name: PROMOTION
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Publicist / Advertiser / Promoter
publicist
advertiser
promoter
Term.Definition: The publicist handles the publicity of a film. They promote the film by issuing press releases and overseeing advertisements
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Advertising Agency
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Advertising Production Company
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Marketing
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: SCRIPT DEPARTMENT
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Treatment / Programme Proposal
treatment
programme proposal
Term.Definition: Person who writes the summary of the ideas covering the focus of the production, the basic story-line, often including Definition of locations, talents, key scenes and approximate times of the segments.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Author / Screenplay / Scriptwriter / Adaptor / Dramatiser
author
screenplay
scriptwriter
dramatiser
adaptor
Term.Definition: A screenplay or script is a blueprint for producing a motion picture or broadcast drama. It can be adapted from a previous work such as a novel, play or short story, or it may be an original work in and of itself. A screenplay differs from a script in that it is more specifically targeted at the visual, narrative arts, such as film and television, whereas a script can involve a blueprint of "what happens" in a comic, an advertisement, a theatrical play and other "blueprinted" creations.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Script Supervisor / Continuity Person
script supervisor
continuity person
Term.Definition: Also known as the "continuity person", the script supervisor keeps track of what parts of the script have been filmed and makes notes of any deviations between what was actually filmed and what appeared in the script, thereby ensuring that consistency is maintained from shot to shot. They also make continuity notes, creating a lined script. The script supervisor works very closely with the director on set
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Assistant Script Supervisor
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Playwright
Term.Definition: A playwright, also known as a dramatist, is someone who writes dramatic literature or drama. These works may be written specifically to be performed by actors
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Storyliner
Term.Definition: Commonly working on television series, storyliners create the plot twists for a given story line, keeping in mind the past storylines for a given character or pairing, and the work with the writers to bring those new plot elements to life.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Idea Originator
Term.Definition: Person whose idea the proposition is based on.
Term.ChangeComment: TVA miantenance 2011

Term.Name: SOUND DEPARTMENT
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Sound Mixer / Mixer
sound mixer
mixer
Term.Definition: Takes care of all sound levels in a studio, on location and in post-production. Head of the sound department. This requires choice and deployment of microphones, choice of recording media, and mixing of audio signals in real time.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Sound Mixer / Head Dialogue
sound mixer
head dialogue
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Sound Mixer / Music
sound mixer
music
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Location Mixer
Term.Definition: A sound mixer responsible for mixing sounds recorded on location
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Sound Supervisor
Term.Definition: Person responsible for the overall quality of the sound production
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Audio Engineer / Sound Engineer / Audio Operator
audio engineer
sound engineer
audio operator
Term.Definition: recording and reproduction of sound through mechanical and electronic means.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Audio Assistant / Sound Assistant
audio assistant
sound assistant
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: First Boom Operator
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Second Boom Operator
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Foley Editor
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Foley Artist
Term.Definition: A person who re-creates incidental sound effects in synchronisation with the visual component for dubbing onto film or video clips. The Foley artist also fabricates sounds that cant be correctly recorded while filming, much like the sound editor does with digital sound effects.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Foley Mixer / Sound Effect Person / Soundman
foley mixer
sound effect person
soundman
Term.Definition: A sound mixer who works with a Foley Artist to create sound effects.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Utility Sound Technician
Term.Definition: Assistant to both the production sound mixer and the boom operator on a film set.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Sound Recordist / Sound Recorder
sound recordist
sound recorder
Term.Definition: A person who operates sound recording devices. The person responsible for recording the sound content of an item. This is more likely to be a role type encountered on location shoots and outside broadcasts as in a studio environment the sound equipement is pre-rigged and will be controlled by the sound mixer.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Film Sound
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Playback Operator
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: STUNTS DEPARTMENT
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Stunt Production Assistant
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Stunt Coordinator
Term.Definition: Stages the stunts and works with the stunt players. Responsible for the safety of all involved in the filming of a stunt.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Stunts / Stunt Performer
stunts
stunt performer
Term.Definition: A person employed to perform stunts within the production.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Utility Stunts
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Stunt Double
Term.Definition: A stunt performer who specifically takes the part of another actor for a stunt. Stunt doubles rarely (if ever) speak, are typically chosen to resemble the actor that they are replacing as much as possible
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Stunt Driver
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Stunt Pilot
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: TALENT
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Key Character
Term.Definition: A character whose appearance in the production is of major importance and who is likely to be an important factor in attracting an audience. Key characters may be real or fictional, and may be animated or played by actors. Examples of Key Characters include Bugs Bunny, Mickey Mouse, Robin Hood, James Bond and Hannibal Lecter.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Key Talents
Term.Definition: Person performing as a leading character in a fiction programme. The presence of this person within the production is regarded as a 'selling point'. That is, the person's presence in the production is expected to be a major attraction to the audience. The classification of a person as a 'key talent' within any given production is an editorial decision and may change over time.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Scenarist
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Essayist
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Sculptor
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Variety Artist
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Voice Over Artist
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Artist / Performer
artist
performer
Term.Definition: A person who plays the role of a character. A person who principally exhibits acting skills in a musical or dramatic presentation or entertainment.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Actor / Actress / Histrion / Thespian / Role Player
actor
actress
histrion
thespian
role player
Term.Definition: A person who plays the role of a character. A person who principally exhibits acting skills in a musical or dramatic presentation or entertainment. It covers the actress or histrion or player or thespian or other role player
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: Anchor / Moderator / Presenter
anchor
moderator
presenter
Term.Definition: A person who introduces, hosts a progarmme or who acts as the central moderator of the programme, responsible for following the programme script towards the audience.

Term.Name: Interviewer
